item.title: Una elegía a mi Washington Post
item.description: Siete principios rectores aún están desplegados en la redacción del periódico, pero ahora más como reproche que como recordatorio.
item.dc:creator: Carlos Lozada

media:content.media:credit: Ilustración de Sam Whitney/The New York Times

item.title: Irán está reconstruyendo instalaciones nucleares y de misiles, según imágenes satelitales
item.description: Las reparaciones en sitios clave de misiles comenzaron poco después de que fueron alcanzados por ataques de Israel y EE. UU. el año pasado, pero el trabajo en las instalaciones nucleares de Irán ha sido más lento.
item.dc:creator: Samuel Granados and Aurelien Breeden

item.title: The Demise of U.S.A.I.D. Was a Warning
item.description: The brutality of U.S.A.I.D.’s closure and the disregard for the human toll betrayed a vision of a crueler, meaner, more insular world.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Konyndyk
item.category: United States Agency for International Development

item.title: Ultraprocessed, Industrial Food Is Fine
item.description: They were at a much higher risk of malnutrition and missed out on the joy of a fresh Sumo orange in February.
item.dc:creator: Jan Dutkiewicz and Gabriel N. Rosenberg

item.title: Paul Thomas Anderson Wins Directors Guild Award for ‘One Battle After Another’
item.description: The filmmaker beat out Ryan Coogler, Guillermo del Toro, Josh Safdie and Chloé Zhao. The prize is a strong predictor of the Oscars.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

media:content.media:description: Paul Thomas Anderson at the Directors Guild Awards on Saturday night.

item.title: Haruki Murakami Isn’t Afraid of the Dark
item.description: The author, who brought Japanese literature into the global mainstream, grapples with aging and his place in the world of letters.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter

media:content.media:credit: Dana Scruggs for The New York Times

item.title: Quote of the Day: Another Danish Territory Feels Trump-Induced Anxiety
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 8, 2026.

item.title: Corrections: Feb. 8, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Feb. 8, 2026.

item.title: What to Know About Japan’s Economy on Election Day
item.description: Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi pushed through a record supplemental budget and is proposing tax cuts, raising questions about how the government will pay for it all.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis

media:content.media:description: A wholesale food market in Sapporo, Japan, in December. The facility is a hub for Japan’s trade, which was disrupted by a geopolitical dispute with China.

item.title: At Least 50 Arrested After Protests Escalate Outside Minnesota Federal Building
item.description: The Whipple Federal Building has become both a staging ground for immigration agents and a hub for demonstrations against the crackdown in the Twin Cities.
item.dc:creator: Bernard Mokam

media:content.media:description: Minnesota State Patrol troopers arresting protesters outside the Whipple Federal Building on Saturday.

item.title: Japan’s Leader Makes a Bold Election Bet. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Sanae Takaichi, who has proved popular as the first woman to lead Japan as prime minister, hopes to bolster her power in a snap election. But she faces hurdles.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández

media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi standing atop a vehicle during an election campaign in Tokyo on Saturday.

item.title: Reaction to Trump’s Racist Post Shows He Is Not Always Immune to Politics
item.description: With the midterm elections nearing, President Trump has found himself in the uncomfortable position of backtracking, even if only by degrees, at key moments.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green

media:content.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump spoke about the video clip of the Obamas on his social media feed as he traveled on Air Force One on Friday.

item.title: What to Know About Thailand’s Election
item.description: The progressive People’s Party was leading in surveys conducted before Sunday’s election but the country has a history of overturning voters’ will.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee

media:content.media:description: Election officials inspecting ballots ahead of their delivery to a local polling station, in Narathiwat, Thailand, on Saturday.

item.title: In Bid to Lead Thailand, a Progressive Party Softens Its Image
item.description: Sunday’s election is a test for the progressive, pro-democracy movement in Thailand, which has been blocked from taking power despite success at the polls.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Kittiphum Sringammuang

media:content.media:description: Natthaphong Ruengpanyawut, the leader of the People’s Party, speaking to supporters in Bangkok on Friday.

item.title: Savannah Guthrie, in New Video, Promises to Pay for Her Mother’s Return
item.description: The “Today” show anchor, in a message on social media with her siblings, said the return of their mother Nancy “is the only way we will have peace.”
item.dc:creator: Reis Thebault

item.title: Brad Arnold, Rocker Who Fronted 3 Doors Down, Dies at 47
item.description: He wrote the band’s breakout hit, “Kryptonite,” in a high school math class, and would go on to be nominated for three Grammy Awards.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor

media:content.media:description: Brad Arnold, center, performing with 3 Doors Down at the Lincoln Memorial in Washington in 2017, in honor of Donald J. Trump’s first inauguration.

item.title: Files Detail Epstein’s Dealings With Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick
item.description: Mr. Lutnick had claimed to have distanced himself from Jeffrey Epstein even before the disgraced financier was convicted of a sex crime in Florida.
item.dc:creator: Michael Rothfeld

media:content.media:description: Documents released by the Justice Department directly contradict Howard Lutnick’s assertion on a podcast last year that he had decided never to be in the same room with Jeffrey Epstein again.

item.title: How Japan’s Kira Kimura Won Gold in Snowboarding Big Air at the Winter Olympics
item.description: Kira Kimura clinched the top spot on the podium after landing two tricks with five and a half rotations.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Cai, Weiyi Cai, Malika Khurana, Victor Mather, Bedel Saget and Jeremy White

item.title: Man Pleads Guilty to Arson in 2019 Attack on Tennessee Civil Rights Center
item.description: The man also pleaded guilty this week to a charge of attempting to provide material support to a foreign terrorist organization, Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler

media:content.media:credit: Capt. Sammy Solomon/New Market Fire and Rescue Team, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: A fire destroyed the main offices of the Highlander Research and Education Center in New Market, Tenn., in 2019.

item.title: Hims & Hers Withdraws Knockoff Weight-Loss Pill After Regulatory Scrutiny
item.description: Federal officials had warned that the new product from the online provider of weight loss drugs might be illegal.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins

item.title: Who’s in Charge Here?
item.description: Chloe Revery’s first Sunday puzzle aces its performance review.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Lovinger

media:content.media:description: Mr. Higgins, measuring your efficiency metrics while you try to solve this puzzle.

item.title: Washington Post C.E.O. Will Lewis Steps Down After Stormy Tenure
item.description: His departure came days after the company cut 30 percent of the staff. He will be replaced in the interim by Jeff D’Onofrio, the chief financial officer, the company said.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin, Katie Robertson and Erik Wemple

media:content.media:description: Will Lewis, the chief executive and publisher of The Washington Post, has stepped down, the company announced Saturday.

item.title: Athletes and Protesters Criticize U.S. Policies at Winter Games in Milan
item.description: Displays of anti-U.S. sentiment have turned up at the Milan Winter Games. Vice President JD Vance was booed at the Olympics opening ceremony, and anti-ICE protesters took to the streets to demonstrate.
item.dc:creator: McKinnon de Kuyper

media:content.media:description: Vice President JD Vance and Usha Vance at San Siro stadium for the opening ceremony of the Winter Olympics in Milan on Friday.

item.title: A Month After Renee Good’s Killing, Her Partner Makes First Public Appearance at Memorial
item.description: Becca Good attended a memorial for Renee Good, offering words of compassion and resilience to the crowd gathered in a snow-covered Minneapolis park.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Becca Good, center, wearing a blue knit cap, made her first public appearance since her partner Renee Good was killed. To her left in a pink cap is Renee’s sister, Annie Ganger. They are attending a memorial in Minneapolis on Saturday.

item.title: Trump’s ‘Board of Peace’ Sets Date to Meet in Washington, Officials Say
item.description: The group, which has prompted skepticism from some U.S. allies, is scheduled to meet on Feb. 19, according to the officials.
item.dc:creator: Natan Odenheimer

media:content.media:description: President Trump during a Board of Peace event at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, last month.

item.title: Thousands in Mississippi Remain Without Power Two Weeks After Winter Storm
item.description: A majority of those who lost service have had their power restored. But thousands in more rural areas remain in darkness, according to a local utility.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hippensteel

media:content.media:description: Utility workers have been on the job for weeks as they try and restore power in Oxford, Miss., after an ice storm late last month.

item.title: 6 Fishermen Reel In a 244-Pound Atlantic Halibut, Setting a Local Record
item.description: The fish, hooked as part of a study on the halibut population around the Ha! Ha! Bay in the Canadian province of Quebec, measured more than 6.5 feet long, researchers said.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker

item.title: Whistle-Blower Report Involved Intelligence About a Trump Contact
item.description: Tulsi Gabbard, the director of national intelligence, moved to lock down an intelligence intercept that referred to someone close to President Trump, the report said.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes

media:content.media:description: The whistle-blower accused Tulsi Gabbard, the director of national intelligence, of limiting who could see the report and of blocking wider distribution among the nation’s spy agencies.

item.title: Ilia Malinin, the ‘Quad God,’ leaves an ace up his sleeve.
item.description: Summary
item.dc:creator: Vincent Alban and Sam Manchester

item.title: Ohio Man Is Charged With Threatening to Kill JD Vance
item.description: During the investigation, the man was found to have child sex abuse materials on his phone, federal prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk

media:content.media:description: An Ohio man made a threat against Vice President JD Vance a day before he was to speak in Toledo, according to a social media post and court records.

item.title: Top ICE Lawyer in Minnesota Departs as Immigration Lawsuits Overwhelm Courts
item.description: Jim Stolley, the chief counsel for U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement in Minnesota, has left as government prosecutors grapple with a crush of cases.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño and Hamed Aleaziz

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Demonstrators at the Bishop Henry Whipple Federal Building in January in Minneapolis. Government lawyers have failed to respond in a timely manner to the pile of lawsuits and court orders stemming from the mass roundup of immigrants.

item.title: A Super Bowl in Silicon Valley Filled With Valley Billionaires
item.description: A who’s who of celebrities will join them. Just a little over 25 percent of the seats for the game will be for regular fans, with the cheapest ticket now selling for more than $4,000.
item.dc:creator: Ken Belson and Mike Isaac

media:content.media:description: The Super Bowl in Silicon Valley “is tech billionaires who got picked last in gym class paying $50,000 to pretend they’re friends with the guys who got picked first,” a venture capitalist said.

item.title: Fake Post About Racist Video Looked to Be Trump’s on Truth Social
item.description: The post, which spread widely, appeared to describe the president’s rationale for deleting a racist video about the Obamas that he had shared.
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The spread of the fake post appeared to be aided in part by the confusion surrounding how President Trump came to post the original racist video and why it was taken down.

item.title: Suzannah Lessard Dies at 81; Stanford White Descendant Who Wrote a Haunting Family Memoir
item.description: Growing up in a family of secrets, on a compound designed by her great-grandfather, made her a writer who investigated the built world with a wary eye.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green

media:content.media:credit: Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Suzannah Lessard in 1996, on the balcony of the Players club in Manhattan, designed by her great-grandfather Stanford White.

item.title: NYC Is Still Covered in Grimy Snow and Ice. Will It Ever Melt?
item.description: Ah, those first wondrous hours of a snowstorm in New York. Two weeks later, the sidewalks are sooty and treacherous, and the parked cars are frozen in surrender.
item.dc:creator: Todd Heisler and John Leland

item.title: Pelosi to Endorse Jack Schlossberg, Again Backing a Kennedy for Congress
item.description: The former speaker, a prodigious fund-raiser and shrewd campaign strategist, seldom intervenes in primaries but has made an exception for a Kennedy before.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Trunsky

media:content.media:description: Nancy Pelosi, left, accepts the 2019 Profile in Courage Award from Jack Schlossberg and his mother, former Ambassador Caroline Kennedy, at the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library in Boston.

item.title: Nithya Raman Announces She Will Run for Los Angeles Mayor
item.description: Nithya Raman, who has been compared to Mayor Zohran Mamdani of New York, presents a significant challenge to the incumbent, Mayor Karen Bass.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan and Shawn Hubler

media:content.media:credit: Stella Kalinina for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Nithya Raman at Los Angeles City Hall in 2022.

item.title: This Is Just Who Trump Is
item.description: The birther of a nation.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie

item.title: What to Know About the Cold Snap in NYC This Weekend
item.description: Cold-weary New Yorkers will get hit by another blast of frigid weather. Here’s what to expect, and what the city is doing to protect the vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: Taylor Robinson

media:content.media:credit: Heather Khalifa for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A biting wind is expected to whip through New York City on Saturday night, creating wind chills of 15 to 25 degrees below zero.

item.title: Easy Chipotle Honey Chicken Wings and More Super Bowl Recipes
item.description: These chipotle honey chicken wings are a fast reader favorite, easy for Sunday’s big game.
item.dc:creator: Mia Leimkuhler

media:content.media:credit: Armando Rafael for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Brett Regot.
media:content.media:description: Christian Reynoso’s chipotle honey chicken wings.

item.title: Saudis Announce New Investments in Syria, a Sign of Deepening Ties
item.description: Saudi and Syrian officials announced deals ranging from aviation to telecommunications, offering a much-needed boost to Syria’s battered economy.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum

media:content.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Construction workers repairing a section of castle walls inside the citadel of Aleppo, Syria, in August. The deals announced on Saturday include the rehabilitation of the city’s airport.

item.title: Why ICE Raids in Minneapolis Are Driving Up Demand for Guns
item.description: Gun permit applications have surged in Minnesota since ICE raids began across the state in December. After weeks of protests and violent confrontations that led to the shooting deaths of two U.S. citizens, we traveled to Minneapolis to speak to some of the new gun owners choosing to exercise their right to bear arms.
item.dc:creator: Michael Anthony Adams, Ben Garvin and Caroline Kim

item.title: Roland Huntford, Lore-Debunking Historian of Polar Exploration, Dies at 98
item.description: He caused an uproar by challenging the heroic status of Robert Falcon Scott, the Briton who led a doomed quest to the South Pole in 1912.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

media:content.media:description: Roland Huntford in 2008. South African by birth, he nevertheless spoke Norwegian fluently and spent 15 years as the Scandinavian correspondent for The Observer, a British newspaper, developing a keen interest in polar expeditions.

item.title: Un poco de arte para ser feliz
item.description: No necesitas tener un supertalento para disfrutar los beneficios.
item.dc:creator: Jancee Dunn

item.title: Valentine’s Day Treats to Fall in Love With Again and Again
item.description: Raspberry and cream éclairs, chocolate lava cake and turtle bars, to name a few.
item.dc:creator: Vaughn Vreeland

media:content.media:credit: Johnny Miller for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Susan Spungen
media:content.media:description: Samantha Seneviratne’s raspberry and cream éclairs.

item.title: Peter Attia, the Epstein Files and the Lie Propping Up Big Wellness
item.description: Health influencers sell themselves as iconoclasts, but many have cozy, uncritical relationships with the rich and powerful.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; source photographs by David Dee Delgado and Davidoff Studios Photography/Getty Images

item.title: A Mosque Bombing Undercuts Pakistan’s Bid for Security
item.description: Pakistan has made headway against the Islamic State and other militants, but a bloody suicide attack showed how fragile its progress has been.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier

media:content.media:description: A funeral on Saturday for victims of a suicide bombing at a mosque on the outskirts of Islamabad, Pakistan, the day before. The attack killed at least 31 people.

item.title: Prediction Markets and Casinos Go to War Over Sports Betting
item.description: Kalshi and Polymarket say their prediction markets are not subject to gambling laws and taxes. The casino industry is lobbying to shut them down as a wave of court cases take on the question.
item.dc:creator: Ian Frisch

media:content.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Bettors legally wager more than $220 billion on sports each year.

item.title: Trump Reverts to Diplomacy With Iran, but the Road Is Narrow
item.description: Iran is skilled at prolonging negotiations over its nuclear program, and seems to be hoping President Trump is out for a quick win, rather than a prolonged regional war.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger

media:content.media:credit: Omani Foreign Ministry, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Steve Witkoff, President Trump’s special envoy, center, and Jared Kushner, the president’s son-in-law, with Oman’s foreign minister, Badr Albusaidi, in a photograph released on Friday by Oman’s Foreign Ministry.

item.title: Trump’s Obama Derangement Syndrome
item.description: The president shows, once again, that he shouldn’t be anywhere near the Oval.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
